awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Turbulent cascades and dissipation in the 3D Navier-Stokes model
awd_abstract_narration:
Grujic
DMS-1515805
Dascaliuc
DMS-1516487

     Turbulence is everywhere, both disruptive and helpful in technological applications, such as safety and efficiency of transportation, biomedical research, climate studies, or infrastructure design.  On one hand, suppressing turbulent drag is key in designing and engineering energy efficient vehicles.  Understanding the genesis and dynamics of a turbulent wake behind a large plane is key in maintaining safety of the airspace in the proximity of an airport.  On the other hand, turbulent mixing may be desirable -- an example being designing more efficient drug delivery systems.  The main theme of the project is a rigorous study of various manifestations of turbulence in three-dimensional fluid flows modeled by the Navier-Stokes equations.  This is considered both from the perspective of the mathematical theory of turbulence, and as a physical mechanism underlying possible blow-ups (singularities) of the solutions of the system.  Ruling out the possibility of singularity formation in any physical model is a fundamental question, even more so when the model should be applicable to such an omnipresent class of physical phenomena as are 3D fluid flows.  Graduate students are included in the work of the project.  

     The project branches into three directions: (1) vortex stretching and local anisotropic diffusion, (2) isotropic diffusion of the velocity field and induced scaling laws, and (3) turbulent transport in non-homogeneous Navier-Stokes model.  The first two directions follow from the recent work of the investigators and their collaborators in presenting a numerically and analytically motivated geometric scenario of vortex filaments formation that exhibits logarithmic sub-criticality in the context of the 3D Navier-Stokes regularity problem.  In this scenario, the transversal scale of the filaments -- a natural, anisotropic micro-scale of the flow -- triggers the mechanism of local, anisotropic diffusion, preventing the possible formation of singularities.  The motivation for the third direction of the study comes from the realm of building and reinforcing mathematical support for Kolmogorov phenomenology in physical scales of the flow.  The investigators have recently managed to adopt their physical scales methodology to the study of forced turbulence.  This opens up an avenue for studying the influence of the spatial distribution of the force on formation of turbulent cascades, as well as for the study of boundary effects via the masking feedback/volume penalization approach.  Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
The main effort of this Project was dedicated to understanding the connection between Physics of turbulent energy transfer across the scales of the fluid flow and mathematical theory of the governing equations -- the Navier-Stokes Equations (NSE). Both Physics of turbulence and Mathematics of the NSE present major unsolved, interrelated challenges. In fact, the mathematical well-posedness of the Navier-Stokes Equations is considered to be one of the seven unsolved "Millennium Problems" in mathematics. 

The research questions raised in this Project impact the society as a whole. Our theoretical results on the NSE could potentially lead to better modeling of a number of phenomena related to fluid dynamics which, through technology transfer, could improve usability and safety of anything from vehicles and airplanes to drug delivery systems, and thus impact the society.

In Physical scales we used approach based on K1K2-averages -- a version of "ensemble" average developed in the course of the previous Project (NSF-1211413). This approach allowed to study turbulent energy cascades in physical scales and mathematically confirm several empirical laws of turbulence directly from NSE. In this Project, we focused on mathematical features of K1K2-averages. We establish several properties of these averages that allow us to use them to partially reconstruct fluctuations of a physical quantity of interest. We used the K1K2-averages to numerically study the inertial ranges -- the ranges of scales where energy is transferred to low scales for simplified models of turbulence.

A possible obstacle to understanding turbulence mathematically may arise form the possibility of "ghost solutions" -- solutions of the NSE that posses the same global physical characteristics, such as energy and enstrophy, but have very different dynamics from what expected physically. We rigorously showed absence of ghost solutions in several regimes, partially confirming the mathematical importance of energy and enstrophy in determining the small-scale dynamics of the fluid flows as modeled by the NSE.

Wa aslo obtained an estimate on the propagation of disturbances in the fluid flow. Imagine you only know local information about the state of the weather and only general information about the globally. Can one use this to make an accurate prediction of the weather in your town? If so, for how long? We answer this question positively in the case of the NSE -- for short enough time. The problem is mathematically complex, since the incompressible NSE are non-local, i.e. one cannot fully reconstruct a solution without knowing information on the global domain, including the boundary conditions.

Finally, we embarked on the study of probabilistic structures that underlie equations of fluid motion. These structures, discovered by Le Jan and Sznitmann in the 1990s, relate to NSE similarly to the way Brownian motion relates to the heat equation. Crucially, the governing equations themselves are deterministic, yet their solutions can be viewed as expectations of quantities build on these random processes. The key difference between the heat equation and NSE is that the stochastic structure corresponding to NSE can be seen in Fourier space and it represents a branching random tree. The fact that the NSE structure branches is not surprising, given the non-linear nature of NSE. Yet, just like in the case of Brownian motion, it provides an important insight into the mechanisms behind propagation of information from the initial data to the solution at time t. It highlights the randomness behind scale-to-scale interactions in fluid flows and points to the presence of governing laws available through the averaging. We establishes general features of these stochastic cascades, focusing on the problem of stochastic explosion -- the possibility of the cascade tree to generate infinitely many branches in finite time. We connect such explosion to non-uniqueness as well as to blow-up of solutions of the underlying deterministic equations. We also prove that these stochastic cascades do in fact explode in some cases, raising possibility of brekdown in well-posedness of the NSE itself.

Overall, the methods and results we developed in the course of our study of mathematical mechanisms behind turbulence, such as space-time localization and K1K2-averages, as well as the stochastic cascade approach to the NSE, may provide new methodology for studying complex, chaotic systems. This Project opened questions for future investigations and we are confident our results will contribute both to mathematical theory of turbulence and to a number of other areas of science, technology, and even daily human activity.

The Project provided opportunity for collaboration with colleagues from several universities, involved training of one postdoctoral scholar, an undergraduate student and two PhD students, including one from the underrepresented groups in Mathematics. The results were presented at numerous local, national, and international conferences and to communities of interest. The team produced seven peer-reviewed publications detailing results of the research, as well as two PhD theses. It sparked new research directions we plan to pursue in the near future.
